Posts.Content: Hi Valerie-anne, I'm asthmatic and my doctor told me that beclomethasone takes about two weeks to become effective. Ventolin will give more immediate results though if you're wheezy. As mentioned above, remember to rinse out your mouth after using your inhalers as they can cause oral thrush. Alternatively, try breathing in the steam from a boiled kettle or bowl of boiled water with the bonus of a facial at the same time! Hope you're less wheezy soon! PinkSquirrel
Posts.Title: wheezing and inhalers

Posts.Content: No. 7 You'll save a fortune on shampoo and conditioner! I'd rather spend the money and keep my hair, thank you very much! And I've spent more money recently buying hats and scarves than I would have spent on shampoo and conditioner!
Posts.Title: Angry !

Posts.Content: It might be worth asking for a fit for work note (sick note) to cover you for a longer period. You can work under a fit for work note but it would save you having to go to the doctor each time and cover you if you aren't fit to be at work when you thought you would be. I took a leave of absence from work during chemo and my HR department asked for a continuous fit for work note to ensure that I was paid during my absence. My GP issued fit for work notes every 3 months with conditions stated as to what I could and couldn't do. A longer fit for work note will also give you some protection if your employer has unreasonable expectations as to what you're able to do.
Posts.Title: Angry over sick note

Posts.Content: Breast MRIs are done with you lying face down with your breasts dangling into spaces in the bed that look like cup holders in a car! My friend asked if testicular MRIs are done in the same way and the imagery of needing three cup holders instead of two amused me! I took a CD of my favourite music to distract me. Take something with a faster beat but nothing that will make you want to shoulder dance or move to the music! If you've got longer hair, tie it back to avoid it annoying you when you can't move. Try wearing an eye mask to distract you from where you are and perhaps help you fall asleep. Ask if you're allowed to have someone with you during the scan that can talk to you and keep you calm. If they're going to use a contrast dye during your MRI, ensure that you've drunk plenty of fluids beforehand to plump up your veins to make the cannula insertion easier. Just remember to visit the loo beforehand as you don't want to be stuck in the MRI machine desperate to pee! : ) The nurses will be able to see and hear you in the MRI machine via a camera and you'll have a panic button in your hand if you need to be removed from the machine if you feel claustrophobic. Good luck!
Posts.Title: MRI tomorrow! Any advice?

Posts.Content: I've been on tamoxifen since March. I can tell when I'm hormonal as I'm decidedly more emotional! I once cried during homes under the hammer as they'd made such a lovely job of renovating an old property. Had to give my head a wobble for that one! : )
Posts.Title: Over Emotional....

Posts.Content: I'm asthmatic and was advised to have the flu jab and the pneumococcal vaccine before starting chemo last year. If you've had surgery, don't have the jab in your surgery side arm! And thank you for reminding me to arrange my flu jab this year!
Posts.Title: Flu jab and chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Sue, I would suggest checking with your oncologist or chemo nurses as to whether you can have the flu jab whilst on chemo. I had to leave x days between the pneumococcal vaccine and starting chemo (either 14 or 21 days, I can't remember). Mention to the chemo nurses if you've had either jab as it might delay your next chemo. PinkSquirrel
Posts.Title: Flu jab and chemo

Posts.Content: You're advised not to eat and drink before surgery in the event that any food or liquids in your system travel back up your oesophagus or make you sick and as you are unconscious, you can't clear you tubes and may choke. My chemo team advised eating small, regular meals to fuel my body. Your body is expending energy to process the chemo drugs so you need to provide your body with additional energy to keep you going. If food stood still long enough during my first chemo, it was mine but I didn't stock my cupboards to the same extent for the subsequent chemos and therefore didn't over eat to the same extent. I too have a layer of insulation that I could stand to lose but I was more focused on getting my body through chemo than trying to lose the weight. Everybody reacts differently to chemo and whilst you may experience adverse side effects, you might also be lucky and experience very few side effects. I would suggest trying your first chemo with food and see how you get on. If you struggle with side effects and medication doesn't help you, then perhaps look at alternative ways of minimising the side effects.
Posts.Title: Fasting along side Chemo - Advice/Thoughts

Posts.Content: Thank you for your replies, they were very helpful. I've started using the R1 & R2 creams rather than the steroid cream and diprobase prescribed by the hospital. I have peely wally fair scottish skin and burn very easily so hopefully the R1 and R2 creams will be beneficial.
Posts.Title: R1 and R2 treatments for skin damage caused by radiotherapy

Posts.Content: I acquired the R1 & R2 creams on prescription and took them to my first radiotherapy session today. I asked if they were okay to use but I was told no as they hadn't been clinically tested by the hospital and they didn't know if the R1 & R2 creams would react with the steroid cream they prescribed (betamethasone valerate topical corticosteroid). I was also advised not to use aloe vera gel for the same reason. The hospital gave me diprobase but I'm tempted to use the R1 & R2 creams. Or should I use the diprobase? Has anyone used the R1 & R2 creams with betamethasone valerate steroid cream and did you have an allergic reaction? And are the R1 & R2 creams better than diprobase?
Posts.Title: R1 and R2 treatments for skin damage caused by radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Karen, I am in a similar position to you as I have one node affected and may require chemo and radiotherapy. Originally I had 2 grade 1 tumours but one has been upgraded to a grade 2 after the lumpectomy. I need another op to ensure clear margins then have to wait for the pathology results. My surgeon has said I will probably need chemo but I don't want to get my hopes up that it won't be required. I think I can get through the next few months but the thought of losing my hair breaks my heart. It's a small thing and I know it will grow back but at the moment it feels like such a big thing. I'm sending you a big virtual hug and I wish you all the best with your decision. Claire
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy with W L E with one node positive

Posts.Content: I've found so many songs with lyrics that I can identify with over the last few months. My anthems have been Kodaline's High hopes (love the video too!) and Brand New day and Birdy's Keeping your head up. And OutKast's Hey ya seemed to be on the radio every day driving to radiotherapy and was in my head when I was trying to stay still whilst being blasted! Kodaline - High hopes www.youtube.com/watch?v=E4povfmX144 Kodaline - Brand new day www.youtube.com/watch?v=rPbJ16OFtuA Birdy - Keeping your head up www.youtube.com/watch?v=m8AXUq5uA0Y OutKast - Hey ya www.youtube.com/watch?v=PWgvGjAhvIw High hopes, when you let it go, go out and start again....
Posts.Title: Anthem

Posts.Content: A very belated thank you for your replies and suggestions. I attempted a second MRI scan last monday but still couldn't do it. I took diazepam beforehand and got as far as going into the machine but I couldn't stay still and I didn't even get as far as the machine being turned on. Thankfully the diazepam chilled me out enough that I didn't have a panic attack this time. Apparently they can't knock you out for a breast scan (possibly as you're face down) and I couldn't go in feet first as I wouldn't have been far enough into the machine for the scan. I tried stretching my arms out in front of me with my forehead resting on my arms but I couldn't get comfy enough to stay still. My lumpectomy went ahead on thursday as planned without the benefit of the MRI scan. My surgeon has warned me that I might need a further operation to ensure all of the cells are removed. I'm hoping I don't need any further MRI scans but if I do, I'll attempt them on a much stronger dose of diazepam!
Posts.Title: MRI claustrophobia

Posts.Content: Today wasn't a good day. I was diagnosed last week with grade 1 invasive ductal carcinoma with the MRI scan today before the pre-op meeting next week. I was more worried about feeling claustrophobic and panicking during the MRI than I am about the lumpectomy and the afterwards. I couldn't keep still during the 4 minute scan so wasn't going to manage the 20 minute scan and the scan was stopped. Then I had a mild panic attach which wasn't fun. I have an appointment with my doctor next week to get a sedative to knock me out a little and attempt the MRI again at a later date. Unfortunately I have to wait two weeks for another MRI appointment which means two weeks of worry that the same thing will happen again. I'm disappointed in myself that I couldn't get through the MRI as it is being done for my benefit. The biopsies didn't faze me but a big magnet made me cry! Has anyone had surgery without the benefit of the MRI? I went into the machine head first and it wasn't the confined space that bothered me as much as having my face surrounded in the hole on the table and not being able to move. It didn't help that I overheated despite the fan being on the maximum setting (possibly part of the panic attack or a hot flush) and couldn't cool down. Is it possible to do the MRI leaning my chin on the table or to the side or resting on my arms so I don't feel so enclosed? Does anyone have any tips or positions to help get through a breast MRI? Any assistance would be greatly appreciated!
Posts.Title: MRI claustrophobia

Posts.Content: Hi Papa Smurf, I obtained the R1 & R2 creams on prescription after I gave my GP a copy of the product data sheet. My local Boots pharmacy were able to fill the prescription as a special order. The PIP codes for the six week treatment pack are R1: 356-4432 (£31.20) and R2: 383-4918 (£41.40) and for the weekly treatment pack 367-3613 (£13.74). Be careful if you have any dairy allergies as both creams contain milk proteins. I was advised to use either diprobase or aveeno with a steroid cream as the R1 & R2 creams hadn't been clinically tested. I've been using the creams against the advise of the radiotherapy clinic nurse but she admitted my skin was looking good after 15 sessions of radiotherapy!  www.radiotherapytreatment.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/Waterjel-R1R2-Radiotherapy-treatment1.pdf www.radiotherapytreatment.com/buy-r1-r2/ www.radiotherapytreatment.com/shop/
Posts.Title: R1 and R2

Posts.Content: I had a lumpectomy in September 2015 and I still have the blue mark from the dye used during surgery - the lesser spotted blue tit! I was warned when I woke up after surgery that my skin might have a blue tinge from the dye and was rather worried that I would wake up looking like a smurf. I have a friend in Canada who is about to have surgery and she will have a clear dye inserted which I'm guessing is a UV dye. She's worried that her breast will glow afterwards which could be interesting under a black light! My blue patch has faded slightly since radiotherapy but I don't know if this is as a result of the radiotherapy or whether it would have faded over time anyway.
Posts.Title: Green boob!

Posts.Content: My pre-chemo straight hair is growing back curly. I'm waiting for my curls will morph into Barbra Streisand's hair at the end of The Way We Were but I currently look like my Grandma. Not the look I was hoping for! : )
Posts.Title: My bald head makes me look like....

Posts.Content: Hi Carol, I also had my second FEC two weeks ago with my next one on hogmanay. I have cold capped both times and whilst my hair has thinned, I still have my fringe and enough hair to keep my head warm! It's thinned a lot on the top and at the back of my head. I knew my hair would thin but I'm not sure if it's thinned more than it should have having used the cold cap. I think it has worked to an extent but I can see where the cap has not been tight against my head. I'm not sure if it's worth cold capping again as I suspect it will be more uncomfortable next time as more of my scalp is exposed. I'll take the advice of the nurses but I think I do want to try it again - what have I got to lose (apart from my hair)? : ) Good luck with your next chemo and I hope the cold cap is successful! PinkSquirrel
Posts.Title: Cold cap & some hair loss

Posts.Content: The joys of a hot flush.... Me at work in a short sleeve summery top with my fan on full blast sat next to my colleague who feels the cold and is wearing a fleece jacket and heavy faux fur coat! I used to have lively debates with another colleague as to whether we should open the window beside us (he complains if I open the window before it reaches 25°C in the office) but now I play the cancer card and use my hot flushes to justify opening the window!
Posts.Title: NOT Pink and Fluffy! RETURNS....

Posts.Content: Hi 58petals, I am in a very similar position to you. I found a lump 4 weeks ago and was diagnosed with grade 1 invasive ductal carcinoma last week. I have 2 small lumps (6mm and 18mm) and I'm scheduled for a lumpectomy at the start of September followed by radiotherapy and 10 years of tamoxifen. I initially thought I would have the lumpectomy, get through the radiotherapy and get back to my life but from researching breast cancer it is starting to dawn on me how much my life changed last week. I'm hoping to return to work after I've recovered from the lumpectomy and hopefully work part-time while I receive the radiotherapy but I'm not sure if I'm being naive hoping to still go to work through this. I'm trying to stay positive - I'm 41 so I'm classed as "young" and my surgeon (who looks like Prince Harry) said he might fill the dent from the lumpectomy with a little fat from my stomach... free liposuction! Although I'm putting on a brave face, like you, I'm very scared. I have so many questions about what is happening, what is going to happen and what the future holds. I feel like I'm about to sit an exam without knowing anything about the subject. I have never joined a forum before but reading through the previous posts and comments has been like opening a door.  I wish you all the best and if you want to talk to someone going through a similar experience, please get in touch. PinkSquirrel
Posts.Title: Diagnosed yesterday...

Posts.Content: I've been trying to source the Genesis brand of tamoxifen for several months now to no avail. I discovered that if pharmacies special order products for you (as opposed to what their suppliers supply them with), they only get paid for their efforts and the cost of the product if you have the brand stated on your prescription. I suspect Genesis is more expensive as few pharmacies seem to stock it whereas Wockhardt, Teva and Mylan are readily available. If your preferred brand is not one of these brands, I would suggest befriending your local independent pharmacist (ie. not Boots / Alliance Healthcare) as they will have access to more suppliers and hence more opportunity to source your preferred brand.
Posts.Title: Does a change in brand of tamoxifen make any difference please?

Posts.Content: If you want to spend a little more money, invest in a tube of Elizabeth Arden 8 hour cream. I use it on my lips when they're dry and it has lots of other uses.
Posts.Title: Looking for a good light (thin) Moisturiser ?

Posts.Content: Different brands can cause varying side effects as the coatings and fillers used in the tablets can vary between manufacturers. You might find that you tolerate and have less side effects with certain brands. If you find a brand that you prefer, ask your GP to state this brand on your repeat prescription otherwise your pharmacy will give you whatever brand they've received from their supplier. I would suggest keeping note of the brand you're taking and any side effects to determine which brand you prefer. Also experiment with the time of day that you take the tablet. I take mine before I go to bed in the hope that I sleep through any side effects - and it makes me sleepy!
Posts.Title: Does a change in brand of tamoxifen make any difference please?

Posts.Content: I discovered Oilatum facial moisturiser during chemo and it really helped my dry skin. Be wary of new products as your skin is more sensitive during chemo and you might have an allergic reaction. I found that my skin looked really good during chemo and I received lots of compliments! I wouldn't recommend chemo as a means to a good complexion but it was an unexpected bonus!
Posts.Title: Looking for a good light (thin) Moisturiser ?

Posts.Content: It's a quote by Elizabeth Edwards who sadly died from cancer. I think it's quite appropriate for the cancer "experience"! : )
Posts.Title: Looking for a good light (thin) Moisturiser ?
